DataElement.preferredName: ALK Inhibitor Most Recent Brigatinib Administered Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The yes/no indicator as to whether the ALK inhibitor, brigatinib, was the most recent drug administered.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: ALK Inhibitor Most Recent Brigatinib Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any agent that inhibits the activity of the receptor tyrosine kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)._Nearest to the present._An orally available inhibitor of receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) with potential antineoplastic activity. Brigatinib binds to and inhibits ALK kinase and ALK fusion proteins as well as EGFR and mutant forms. This leads to the inhibition of ALK kinase and EGFR kinase, disrupts their signaling pathways and eventually inhibits tumor cell growth in susceptible tumor cells. In addition, AP26113 appears to overcome mutation-based resistance. ALK belongs to the insulin receptor superfamily and plays an important role in nervous system development; ALK dysregulation and gene rearrangements are associated with a series of tumors. EGFR is overexpressed in a variety of cancer cell types._The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any agent that inhibits the activity of the receptor tyrosine kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK).

Concepts.definition: An orally available inhibitor of receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) and the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) with potential antineoplastic activity. Brigatinib binds to and inhibits ALK kinase and ALK fusion proteins as well as EGFR and mutant forms. This leads to the inhibition of ALK kinase and EGFR kinase, disrupts their signaling pathways and eventually inhibits tumor cell growth in susceptible tumor cells. In addition, AP26113 appears to overcome mutation-based resistance. ALK belongs to the insulin receptor superfamily and plays an important role in nervous system development; ALK dysregulation and gene rearrangements are associated with a series of tumors. EGFR is overexpressed in a variety of cancer cell types.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).
